reviews.review_msg: This class is fairly easy because of all the sample midterms and finals he provides. The class project takes some time, but is easier than it seems at first.

Good prof. You learn a lot, but be prepared to spend a lot of time on assignments. Assignments /labs were pretty vague, but it made you learn a lot. Use the TA and office hours! Overall a good prof and I would recommend, but be prepared to work and find a good group.
No Good. Very vague expectations, specially on lab materials. Multiple choice questions for a system analysis course?!! Not impressed.
No Comments

He is nice and very willing to help. His exams are too easy and don't create enough variance for the curve. I would recommend him. He could be a little more clear when it comes to expectations. He provided tons of past exams though, which is nice.
He is a good lecturer but is not the most helpful. Sometimes class seemed to come second after his outside business interests.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Richard is a great guy! The grading of the project deliverable/assignments are somewhat unclear which make some students stressed. He's able to teach course content in a way that's easy to understand. Overall, class was good. Expect lots of project work (and get a good group)
Mediocre teaching ability and assignment heavy. He's available for help, though. Live or die by group projects and weekly assignments; TA's are often unavailable / unhelpful.

Despite it being Drew's first semester teaching online, he adapted well and guided students through the semester with ease. Lab assignments were well set up and the midterm and final did a good job of testing theory. One thing that stood out for me was the high level of respect Drew had for his students, in the form of trust and open communication.

Drew is one of my all-time favorite professors, he's been at SFU for so long and he still has a fondness for teaching. He was incredibly funny, spent time making sure course material was relevant and his office hours are great because you can ask him anything. He helped me a ton in how to set myself apart in my career and is just a gem.
Best prof ever, super considerate, helpful, care and fair to students, fair exam, great teaching style

Great prof. Makes good jokes and is always in good spirit. Fairly easy marking so long as you know at least a bit of what you are talking about. Exams are purely application and not memorizing. Would definitely take another course with Drew!
No Comments

Approachable and insightful. Tailors the course for workplace applications, but doesn't prioritize grade standardization as much as profs in other courses, making class averages high (~90%). Fierce competition for low-A's. Group projects aren't too bad if you have a good group.

Honestly I really enjoyed Dr. Nasr's BUS 362 course. She is very passionate about the subject and does her best to keep the class engaged throughout her lectures. She is very accessible outside of lecture hours and genuinely wants to see her students succeed. It's a 4 credit course so yeah, expect some work.
no complaints but expect lots of work
Fair and interesting class and professor - my tip - stay on top of your work (regular meetings) and the workload is very manageable.

I'll be honest, I have no idea what the other reviews are talking about, Dr. Nasr is a great professor, her lectures are very applicable and interesting and all of her assignments are fair. It's a 4 credit course so it's a given that there will be more work to do but nonetheless, it's great.

I hated this course so much because of the disorganization. She told us in the beginning of the semester that the 2 midterms will NOT be cumulative and then a week before the second midterm (now called a final), is cumulative. AVOID her at all costs.

Eman is extremely disorganized and decided to change due dates last minute, moving up the final project and other assignments. There is no time to work on the final project - meaning you would have to do it all out of class with your group. She also does weekly quizzes of stuff she doesn't even teach in class so you should read the textbook

She is one of the most boring professors I've had at SFU. Her lectures are dry and she makes up examples on the spot rather than having them prepared, meaning most of the time it does not match what the textbook is showing(follow the textbook and not her examples). She does not give any instructions on the assignments and refuse to answer questions

Amir is obstinate and does not give good guidance.  He is very difficult to work with and does not seem to know how to teach (perhaps he just doesn't know the program material).   Does not get back to you in a timely manner.

Amir is very knowledgable and has a genuine care for his students. His exams are quite difficult so be prepared. Make sure to participate because he will call on you randomly or give out bonus marks for participation. Quirky and likes to joke around. Solid choice.

Definitely knowledgeable in the field. EXTREMELY difficult marker; looks for specifics and key words in answers. Exams are definitely on the hard side-you must know material VERY WELL. Instructions on project & assignments are sometimes unclear; seems that the TA and him haven't communicated very well. However, both Kamal and TA are always helpful.

Lectures were relatively interesting - Landon had a dry sense of humour that not enough people appreciate. However, I did not learn anything from Landon and there is too much work in this class. Your group matters in this course since there are weekly group assignments, two group reports, and a group presentation.
Landon is a great professor. He is a little bit dry, but overall his lectures are enjoyable and the class content interesting.
Way far behind your standard. Very boring and unclear.  Not sure if he knows how to teach

Horrible. Lecture slides literally needed 5 staples because he has too many slides and he doesn't even go through all of them. He is unhelpful and unclear. A nice guy, but finishes last on my prof list!

Lectures were unorganized and he would skip slides, add and remove slides last minute. Many slides he used are copied from a 2008 ppt found online. Exams, while not too hard, were made poorly and open to highly subjective marking. Assignments were unclear, lengthy and required BUS462 knowledge. Errors were present in the solutions he provides
